Annabel Rothschild

Art

Mostly I keep this record as a list of inspirations, but in no particular order:

  • Hilma af Klint.
  • W.E.B. Du Bois’ (and his teams’) visionary infographics
  • Fatima al-Fihri founded the oldest university in the world, the University of al-Qarawiyyin in 859 CE which is wild to think about.
  • Mimi Ọnụọha is! so! cool! Hearing her speak at an event at Wellesley was super amazing and an experience I’m very grateful for.
  • A list of programming langauges (co)created by women, put together by Dr. Chris Martens.
  • Carrie Mae Weems produces such brilliant, thought-provoking (and beautiful) work on a variety of important, pressing topics.
  • I Was Raised on the Internet is perhaps one of the best exhibitions I’ve ever had the chance to see.
  • I hope to one day see Radical Women: Latin American Art, 1960–1985 in its entirety. Graciela Carnevale, Cecilia Vicunã, and Nelbia Romero amaze me with their ability to communicate such hefty messages through their respective visual mediums.
  • I find Kathë Kollwitz’s work eternally poignant, too.
  • Tove Jansson is another long time inspiration.
  • An excellent book about life in academia: Dr. Hope Jahren’s.
  • Cindy Sherman’s Untitled Film Stills. I do grapple, however, with the tableaus in some of her other work (and the experiences they represent – or perhaps appropriate or mock might be better words).
  • I admire the way Yael Bartana expresses her politics through art.
  • hana vu makes cool music.
  • Etta James
  • Helga Weyhe
  • ✉️: kontakt@thisdomain
  • Impressum.
